sep=: Conduct informal meeting to explain topic
column4: In the academic context, it is a common best practice for students to have an informal meeting to discuss and understand the thesis topic before officially accepting it. This helps ensure that the student is fully informed and engaged in the research process.

sep=: Conduct informal meeting to explain topic
column4: The best practice in this academic setting is to first have an informal meeting to explain the thesis topic to the student before they start writing the thesis. This allows the student to understand the topic better and decide if they are interested in it before committing to writing the thesis.

sep=: Conduct informal meeting to explain topic
column4: The order of conducting an informal meeting to explain the topic before conducting regular catch-up meetings is a best practice commonly followed in academic settings to ensure that the student has a good understanding of the topic before engaging in regular catch-up meetings to discuss progress and updates.

sep=: Conduct informal meeting to explain topic
column4: In academia, it is a common best practice for students to have an informal meeting to discuss and explain their thesis topic before officially submitting it. This helps ensure that the topic is well-understood and agreed upon by both the student and the supervisor before proceeding with the submission.

sep=: Conduct informal meeting to explain topic

Writing and submitting a proposal is a common practice before officially accepting a thesis, as it helps outline the scope and objectives of the thesis work.

In academic settings, it is a common best practice to first write and submit a proposal outlining the research plan before starting to write the actual thesis. This helps in clarifying the research objectives, methodologies, and timelines before diving into the detailed writing process.

The context mentions that it is common for supervisors to have regular weekly or bi-weekly meetings to ensure the student is on track with their thesis. While it is not a university rule, it is a practice that is usually followed by supervisors to support the progress of the thesis. Therefore, conducting regular catch-up meetings is considered a best practice in this scenario.
